query:
1. On the HPE GreenLake platform header,
click the workspace menu and then select Manage
Workspace.
2. Click Audit Log.
3. On the Audit Log page, click the Export
Log button.
The Export Log dialog box displays.
4. Select the file type that you want to export. Options include
.CSV or PDF file types.
NOTE:
Audit log PDF exports can only support a maximum of six
table columns.
5. Select the Table Entries and Table
Columns you want to include in the exported file.
* Select Current Search Result to export only
the files from your current search results.
* Select Entire Audit Log to export the entire
audit log.
6. Click Save after you make your selections.
The file with your selections downloads to your computer.

1. On the **Devices** page, click the **Inventory** tab.
2. In the Inventory section, click the  Require Service Manager
Assignments card.
The inventory list displays all devices requiring
assignments.
3. Use the check boxes to select the devices you want to assign to a
service.
4. From the Actions drop-down, click Assign to
Service Manager.
If you have multiple workspaces, the Select a Workspace
page appears with the list of your existing workspaces.
5. Select a workspace and click Next.
6. On the Assign Devices
to Service Manager Instance page, from the drop-down lists,
select a Service Manager instance and a
Region (for the service instance) to assign your
devices.
A Devices Assigned dialog
appears.
7. Click **View Audit Log** to check the audit logs for assignment activity
details, otherwise, click **Close**.
8. Click Finish.

1. Click **Service Subscription** on the vertical tab.
2. Click **Add Service Subscription**.
3. Enter the subscription key that you received in your email.
4. Click **Submit**.
NOTE: You can view all your subscriptions in the **Service Subscriptions**
vertical tab.

1. On the Devices page, click the **Inventory**
2. In the Inventory section, click the Total Devices
card.
3. Use the check boxes to select the device you want to archive.
4. From the Actions drop-down, click
Archive.
5. Click Archive Devices to confirm your action.
After you finish archiving your devices, you can view the changes
in the
Archive devices no longer in service. Archiving devices removes them from the\ninventory list
You must set up services before adding subscriptions. See Adding Services to your\nWorkspace.
The Inventory section on the **Devices** page enables you to assign, update, or\neven remove the subscription of a device from a Service Manager instance.
You must create a support request to get access to HPE GreenLake platform APIs

1. While logged in to HPE GreenLake platform, click Help & Support
2. In the Help section, selectHPE GreenLake.
3. In the Support section, select Workspace,
User, and Onboarding Support.
4. Fill in the requested details.
* Enter your name, company name, email, and phone number.
* Choose your preferred contact method, either email or phone.
* In Support Issue Details, in What do you
need help with?, choose HPE GreenLake
platform API onboarding.
* Provide the workspace name and the email address associated with it. To find
your workspace name, click **Manage**, then click **User** to get
the workspace user email address.
5. Click Submit.
A ticket is created with HPE GreenLake
support. Expect a resolution within 24 hours.
The Inventory section on the **Devices** page summarizes your device\ninformation and provides a set of actions to manage all your devices and their\nsubscriptions.
Users with edit permissions through the Authorization\nservice can create resource restriction policies (RRPs).

RRPs are named groups of resources that you can create and
customize to manage who can access your resources. You can limit access to resources by
applying these policies when you make user role assignments.Create Resource Restriction
Policy
**wizard**
When you create an RRP, the Create Resource Restriction
Policy wizard guides you through a four-step resource selection
procedure. In this procedure, you can name the policy, associate it with an service
manager in a region, select the resources and scope instances, review, and save it.
After the RRP is created, you can apply it to user roles to restrict the resources
users can access.

1. On the HPE GreenLake platform header,
click the workspace menu and then select Manage
Workspace.
2. On the Manage
Workspace page, click the Identity &
Access card.
3. On the  Identity &
Access page, click the Resource Restriction Policy
Card.
The Resource Restriction
Policies page appears.
4. Click Create Resource Restriction Policy.
The Create Resource Restriction Policy wizard
screen appears where you can enter details for the new policy.
5. In the (Step 1) Add
Name & Description screen, enter a
Name and a Description for the
RRP and click Next.
6. In the (Step 2) Choose
a Service Manager screen, select the service manager for which
you want to limit access and click Next.
The Add Resources screen appears.
7. In the (Step 3) Add
Resources screen, click the Add Resources
button.
The Add
<Service Manager> Resources screen appears.
8. Select the service that your policy can access. The resource options vary by
service.
1. Click to select an service region from the list. The number of
available services for the region are displayed on the screen.
2. Click a scope resource name in the left pane to view its constituent
scope instances listed in the right pane.
NOTE: There can be more than one level of resource
groupings. In such cases, click the scope resource name to show the
next sub-resource group.
3. Next, select the check boxes for the scope instances that you want to
include in the policy. You can select a predefined group filter from the
top right section of the Add <service
manager name> Resources screen, or individual scope
instances from the All Resources section below
NOTE:
* Group filters include multiple scope instances.
Selecting a group filter disables the check boxes in the
All Resources section. If you prefer to
select individual scope instances from the All
Resources section, you must first clear the
group filter check box.
* The All
Resources (scopes) section shows up to 200
scope instances. If your workspace has additional scope
instances that are not shown on the page, you can use the
search field to find them.
As you add them, the number of scopes added to the
policy are incremented and displayed on the bottom of the
screen.
4. When you have finished selecting scopes, click
The Selected
Resources section on the Add
Resources screen lists the resources selected for this
new policy: scope resources are displayed in bold font with their member
scope instances listed below them.
5. At this point, you can click the Add Resources
button to repeat these steps and add more resources to the policy.
6. When you have completed adding resources, click
Next.
The Review &
Create screen appears.
9. In the (Step 4) Review
& Create screen, verify the settings for your RRP. Use the
Modify links to change the policy name, description,
service manager, or resources.
10. Click Finish to create the RRP.
The Resource Restriction Policies page displays the newly created
policy.
If you have multiple workspaces, you can easily switch between those workspaces\nand manage them independently.

HPE GreenLake platform supports sorting
capabilities on **Workspace**, **Created** and **Last Visited** columns for customer
workspaces. MSP administrators can alphabetically sort the workspaces column, and the Created
and Last Visited columns in ascending or descending order. Click the column heading to change
the sorting arrow direction

In December 2023, we redesigned HPE GreenLake platform to be more user friendly, easy to navigate and showcase the\nexpanded services available from HPE GreenLake platform

The new HPE GreenLake platform
provides a quick visual and access to HPE GreenLake platform features and services from a single location. The new layout allows easy
access to the services you utilize the most, along with links to resources for various HPE GreenLake platform functionality.
Here are the main changes:

Home page layout
|  | **Home page sections** | **Descriptions** | **Actions** |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 1 | **HPE GreenLake platform header** | The main navigation menu bar contain links to  three areas: Home, Services and Devices | Gives you the visibility and control to centrally manage your  services. |
| 2 | **Getting Started** | Getting started section contains cards to quickly discover and  access services from the service catalog and manage your workspace. | **Find services** Navigates to Service catalog page **Manage Workspace** - Navigates to the manage page where you  setup, invite and manage users and their workspace. |
| 3 | **Quick Links** | Quick Links available:* Manage Workspace * Device Inventory * Service Subscriptions * User Management * Locations * Switch Workspace * Feedback | **Manage Workspace** navigates to the Manage  Workspace page.**Devices** **Inventory** navigates to  the Devices page.**Service Subscriptions** navigates to  the Services > Subscriptions page.**User Management**  navigates to the Users list page.**Locations** navigates to the Create  Location page.**Switch Workspace** navigates to the My  Workspaces page.**Feedback** navigates to General Feedback page.. |
| 4 | **Recent Services** | New users see the following message: “You  haven’t launched any services yet. View the services catalog to get  started”  If you previously provisioned or  launched services, those services are shown under Recent Services. | Provides an edge-to-edge cloud platform that comes to users  wherever your apps or data live. |
| 5 | **Learn section** | Learn section has the following cards:* HPE GreenLake Developer  Portal * What’s new on HPE  GreenLake | HPE GreenLake Developer Portal  - Brings you to the GreenLake Developer Portal. What’s new on HPE GreenLake -  Opens our What’s New page, where we tell you about the latest features. |
| 6 | **Featured Services** | Below is a list of menu options available under Featured  Services:* Recommended * Private Cloud * Compute * Storage * Networking * Workloads * Management and Governance | Each tab has a number, indicating the number of services listed on  each tab.   After services are moved to the recent services section they are  removed from the list of featured services. |

Listed below are the major user interface and name changes:
* “**Application**” is renamed to “**Service**” or “**Service**
**Manager**”
* The **Dashboard** is now the **Home** page.
* **Device**
**Subscriptions** and **Tags** are now on the **Devices** page.
* You now manage your **Service Subscriptions** on the **Services**
page.
* **HPE GreenLake Central** is renamed to **HPE GreenLake Flex
Solutions**
* The **What’s**
**New** card replaces the **Release**
**Notes** card on the home page. The release notes are still accessible from the
**What's New** page.

You install the Google Authenticator app on your mobile device for multifactor
authentication. During the registration process, HPE GreenLake platform shares a secret key with the user's mobile device
over a secure channel when the user logs in to HPE GreenLake platform. The key is stored in the Google Authenticator app
and used for future logins. When you register your mobile device successfully, the
Google Authenticator app generates a six-digit token for the second-level
authentication.
1. Once multifactor authentication (MFA) is enabled for your company workspace,
log in to HPE GreenLake platform
with your credentials.
2. On the **Setup Multi-factor Authentication** page, select Google
Authenticator, then click **Setup**.
3. Follow the vendors' instructions for downloading and configuring the Google
Authenticator app. NOTE: After your authentication factors
are configured, you have the option of selecting another authentication
factor.
4. Follow the instructions on the **Set up multifactor
authentication** page to complete the setup.When you next
log in, you will have to enter a code that is generated by the Google
Authenticator app on your phone to confirm your identity.

You can configure MFA for users who log in to a workspace with their credentials.\nOnce you enable MFA for the workspace, all workspace users are prompted to set up\nMFA authentication when they next log in to HPE GreenLake platform.

1. On the HPE GreenLake platform header,
click the workspace menu and then select **Manage Workspace**.
2. Click the Workspace Details card on the Manage Workspace
page.
3. Click the **Security** tab.
4. On the Multi-Factor Auth page, click Edit
Details.
5. Slide the Enabled with Google Authenticator toggle
button to the right.
6. Click Save Changes.
MFA is enabled for all the users associated with the
workspace.

# Enabling MFA for user workspaces

## About this task

You can configure MFA for users who log in to a workspace with their credentials.
Once you enable MFA for the workspace, all workspace users are prompted to set up
MFA authentication when they next log in to HPE GreenLake platform.

## Procedure

1. On the HPE GreenLake platform header,
click the workspace menu and then select **Manage Workspace**.
2. Click the Workspace Details card on the Manage Workspace
page.
3. Click the **Security** tab.
4. On the Multi-Factor Auth page, click Edit
Details.
5. Slide the Enabled with Google Authenticator toggle
button to the right.
6. Click Save Changes.
MFA is enabled for all the users associated with the
workspace.
Click the **Auto-Subscribe** tab on the **Devices** page to configure\nautomatic subscription for supported devices including switches, gateways, and access\npoints

The HPE Sustainability
Insight Center displays charts
showing carbon emissions, energy consumption, and energy cost aggregated across the
IT estate, and a data table that breaks down the data at the individual device
level.
Use the information to understand your IT carbon
footprint, manage your IT operating costs, and stay ahead of regulations. Specify
time ranges before you run reports to identify trends in your total consumption;
then take actions to reduce consumption across your IT estate and use the HPE Sustainability
Insight Center to monitor their
effectiveness.
NOTE: Electrical grid emissions factors and
cost-per-kWh values are calculated based on location. Devices without an assigned or
designated location receive a default value.

The Carbon Emissions chart displays the carbon emissions
produced by your IT estate over specified periods.
* View an up-to-date snapshot of the emissions associated with the total energy
consumption of all devices in your IT estate (devices managed by Compute Ops
Management and Compute Ops Management - OneView
Edition).
* View the emissions associated with the total energy consumption of all devices
in your IT estate (over time) to understand current emissions in terms of
historical data and identify trends in emissions.
* Change the period over which you view the emissions associated with the total
energy consumption over time and focus on a period of greatest interest to

The Energy Consumption chart displays the energy consumed
by your IT estate over specified periods.
* View the most recent aggregation, over a specified period, of the total energy
consumption of all devices in your IT estate.
* View the energy consumption of all devices in your IT estate as a function of
time to understand current energy consumption in terms of historical data and
identify trends in total IT energy consumption.
* Change the period over which you view the energy consumption as a function of
time and focus on a period of greatest interest to you

The Energy Cost chart displays the energy costs incurred
by your IT estate over specified periods.
* View an up-to-date snapshot of the cost associated with the total energy
consumption of all devices in your IT estate.
* View the cost associated with the total energy consumption of all devices in
your IT estate over time to understand the current cost in terms of historical
data and identify trends in cost.
* Change the period over which you view the cost associated with the total energy
consumption over time and focus on a period of greatest interest to you.

The Export function allows you to download reports from the
HPE Sustainability
Insight Center. Use the export
function to save the historical energy consumption, emissions, and cost data for
your entire IT estate over a defined period as a comma separated values (.CSV) file
that can be shared with associates or referenced offline.

You can enable IP address based access control for your HPE GreenLake platform workspaces.
From the IP Access
Rules page, limit user access to your workspace based only on the IP addresses
specified here. Limit workspace access by specifying single IP addresses, IP subnet masks, or
IP address ranges.
NOTE: This feature requires the use of public IP addresses instead of the
private IP addresses provided by your DHCP server.
Once enabled, only IP addresses specified in the access rules can access the
workspace. When users with IP addresses that are not included in the access rules try to
access the workspace, they see:* An Access
Restricted notification.
* A message on the workspace login link indicating that the IP address block
is in effect and a Contact Support link for assistance.

Use the Security tab on the **Workspace Details** page
to configure multifactor authentication (MFA) for your company workspace users. Once you
enable MFA, the next time users log in to the workspace they are required to set up one of the
supported MFA methods before gaining access. MFA adds an extra layer of security to your
workspace resources by adding a second step of verification when users sign in.
HPE GreenLake platform supports the
following MFA solutions for computers and mobile phones. It is recommended that you enable and
configure two different methods of MFA to avoid potential lockouts.
* Okta Verification
* Security Key or Biometric Authenticator
* Google Authenticator
You must add a device subscription key to your workspace independently of adding a\nspecific device

1. On the **Devices** page, click the **Device Subscriptions** tab.
2. Click Add Device Subscriptions.
3. In the Add Device
Subscription dialog box, enter the Subscription
Key that was sent with your device.
4. Click Submit. You can continue adding license keys as
needed.
The subscriptions are now available to assign to devices in your
workspace.

Use the Devices page to view all your devices in one place, search for a
device, or see the subscription status of your devices. You can also view detailed
information about a device. The Details page also
shows the configuration of any storage devices that are composed of multiple modules
in one or more chassis (for example, for block storage devices)

1. On the Devices page, click
Inventory.
The Devices page opens
displaying the Inventory table.
* The Inventory table lists the total
number of devices including access points, switches, and controllers in
the inventory.
* The filter cards at the top of the list display the total number of devices,
assigned and subscribed devices, devices requiring service assignments,
and devices requiring subscription in the inventory.
2. (Optional) Select a row in the Inventory table to open
the Details page and view detailed information about the
device.
If the device is a block storage device with multiple modules you can view the
configuration in the Chassis section, and you can
expand each chassis to view the module information.
3. (Optional) Filter the list of devices.
* Use the cards, filter, or search field to filter the list of devices.
* If you are an MSP user, use the All Workspace(s)
drop-down list to filter by workspace.
The following table describes the columns in the Device
List table.
| Column | Description |
| --- | --- |
| Serial Number | The device serial number |
| Model | Hardware model of the device |
| MAC address | MAC address of the device |
| Service Manger | Service assigned to the device |
| Service Region | Region where the service instance is deployed (where the largest number  of devices are assigned) |
| Subscription Tier | Subscription tier assigned to the  device |
| Tags | Tags assigned to the device |
Users with edit permissions through the authorization service can\nedit existing resource restriction policies (RRPs)

Resource restriction policies (RRPs) are resource groupings that
you can use to customize and limit permissions when you make user role assignments. When
you edit an RRP, you can update the policy name, description, service, and scopes
associated with it.

1. On the HPE GreenLake platform header,
click the workspace menu and then select Manage
Workspace.
2. On the Manage
Workspace page, click the Identity &
Access card.
3. On the  Identity &
Access page, click the Resource Restriction Policy
Card.
The Resource Restriction Policies page appears.
4. Click on a resource restriction policy in the list.
The RRP details screen appears.
Edit Details5. In the Details section, click Edit to update the
RRP name and description.
The name and description fields become editable and you can
make your changes in the text fields.
6. Click Save Changes to update the information.
Edit Resources7. In the Resources section, click
Edit.
The Add Resources and Save
Changes buttons appear. Delete icons appear next to each listed
resource.
8. Click the delete icon next to a resource to remove it from the policy.
9. Click Add Resources to begin selecting new resources for
this policy.
The Add
<service manager name> Resources screen
appears.
10. Click to select an service manager region from the list. The number of
available services for the region are displayed on the screen.
11. Click a scope resource name in the left pane to view its constituent scope
resources listed in the right pane.
NOTE: There can be more than one level of resource
groupings. In such cases, click the resource name to show the next
sub-resource group.
12. Next, select the check boxes for the scopes that you want to include in the
policy. You can select a predefined group filter from the top right section of
the Add <service
manager name> Resources screen, or select individual scopes
from the All Resources section.
NOTE:
* Group filters include multiple scopes. If you prefer to
select individual scope resources from the All
Resources section, you must clear the group filter
check box.
* The scopes section shows up to 200 scopes. If your
workspace has additional scopes that are not shown on the page, use
the search field to find scopes defined in your workspace.
As you add them, the number of resources added to the policy
are incremented and displayed on the screen.
13. When you have finished selecting scopes, click Add.
The Add
Resources screen closes and you can see the updated resources
listed in the Resources section of the policy details page.
14. Click Save Changes to save the updated policy.

1. On the HPE GreenLake platform header,
click the workspace menu and then select Manage
Workspace.
2. On the Manage
Workspace page, click the Identity &
Access card.
3. On the  Identity &
Access page, click the Invite Users
Card.
The Users page appears.
4. Click a name to select a user from the list.
The user details screen appears.
5. Click the ellipsis (...) next to the service resource
you want to modify.
A pop-up window displays the available actions (options
vary depending on the selected service and role).
6. Select the Edit Resource Access link.
The Edit
Resource Access dialog appears and the number of assigned RRPs
are listed in the Resource Restriction Policy
field.
7. Click the down arrow to access and select the policies from the drop-down list.
Use the check boxes to select new policies or clear existing assignments.
NOTE: You can select multiple RRPs for the user
role.
8. Click Save Changes.
The dialog closes and a confirmation notification for the policy updates
appears. Click X to dismiss the notification.
9. To verify the change, select the Limited Access link In
the user details screen.
The Limited Access pop-up window lists the policies
applied to the role assignment.
Use the Workspace\nDetails page to view and manage general information and multifactor\nauthentication for your company workspace.
Ensure that you have the Workspace Administrator privileges on the HPE GreenLake platform.

Set up this integration to view the power metrics data for devices managed through
Compute Ops Management - OneView
Edition on the HPE Sustainability
Insight Center.

To manage servers only through Compute Ops Management - OneView
Edition, follow the steps in [Configuring Compute Ops Management - OneView
Edition](https://support.hpe.com/hpesc/public/docDisplay?docId=sd00001293en_us&page=GUID-CA2BF1A7-7F1F-4A4C-B5E8-C02352638588.html).
NOTE: To manage servers directly with HPE GreenLake for Compute
Ops Management, or with both direct management and Compute Ops Management - OneView
Edition, follow [Configuring Compute Ops Management direct management
and optional HPE OneView edition](https://support.hpe.com/hpesc/public/docDisplay?docId=sd00001293en_us&page=GUID-8F12FE6C-DC13-44DC-921B-041E8DC628DB.html)
You must have an HPE account and be a member of\na workspace on HPE GreenLake platform

Request an evaluation subscription for either the Compute Ops Management or the
Backup & Recovery service on HPE GreenLake platform to try out the service and assess if it is appropriate for your
business needs before buying.
NOTE: Within a workspace, you can have only one active evaluation
subscription for a specific service at a time. However, you can have evaluation
subscriptions for more than one service concurrently. For example, you might have
evaluation subscriptions for both Backup & Recovery and Compute Ops Management
services.

1. Log in to HPE GreenLake platform.
2. On the **Services** page, click the **Catalog** tab.
3. On the **Services Catalog** page, search for the service you want to
evaluate. To restrict your search to services that offer evaluation
subscriptions:
1. Click the Filter icon.
2. Click **Evaluation Available** in the
Evaluations section of the **Filters** panel.
3. Click **Apply Filters**.
4. In the search results, select the card for the relevant service.
The page for the selected service is displayed.
5. Click **Request Evaluation**.
6. Enter the following details on the **Request Evaluation** panel:
* **Business email**— Enter your business email address. You cannot use a
web-based email address such as GMail or Yahoo Mail to request an
evaluation subscription. If you do not have a business
email address, contact your HPE
representative in sales or product support.
* **Company**—Enter the company name.
* **Address**—Enter the full address of the company.
* **Phone Number**—Enter a contact phone number.
* **Server Family**—Select the server family (Compute Ops Management
only).
* **Deployment**—Select the region where you want to deploy the service. You
can deploy the service to additional regions later.
7. Click **Terms of Service** to review the terms that apply to the evaluation
license, then click the checkbox to accept the terms.
You must accept the terms of service to proceed with the evaluation
request.
8. Click **Request Evaluation**.
9. Check the Notifications Center for status updates on your evaluation request.
It can take up to 24 hours for the request to be reviewed and approved.
After the evaluation request is successfully submitted it is assigned a status
of **Pending**. The status changes to **Accepted** once the request is
approved. You then receive a notification with a link to the service URL and
the next steps to get started. The evaluation license key details are also
emailed to you.
NOTE: If the request for an evaluation license is not
accepted, click the link **Submit a support request** included in the
refusal notification to find out why the request was declined.
10. Once you complete the steps outlined in the notification, you can start to use
the service.
Each time you navigate to the service page to launch the service,
a message is displayed showing your evaluation subscription expiry date and the
number of days before the subscription expires.

A tag is a form of metadata applied to any resource and primarily used to
categorize resources based on purpose, owner, environment, or other criteria. A tag is a
key-value pair attached to a HPE GreenLake platform
and services resource.

HPE GreenLake platform supports the
following specification for all services across the platform.
NOTE: Users should not store any Personal Identifiable Information
(PII) in the tags.
* Resources that support tagging can support up to 25 tags per resource.
* Tag keys and values are case-insensitive.
* There can be only one value for a particular tag key for a given
resource.
* Null is not allowed as a possible value for a tag key. Instead, an empty
string ("") is supported so you can use tag key-value pairs for a label use case.
* System-defined tags are allowed and start with the prefix **hpe**.
User-defined tags cannot start with this prefix.
* A tag key must have 1-128 characters.
* A tag value can have a maximum of 256 characters.
* Allowed characters are letters, numbers, spaces representable in UTF-8, and
the following characters: \_ . : = + - @.

Identify the SAML SSO metadata from the IdP that you need to add to HPE GreenLake platform. If you want to add this\ninformation from a metadata file or metadata URL, have the XML file or URL\navailable

On the HPE GreenLake platform header,
click the workspace menu and then select Manage
Workspace.
2. On the **Manage Workspace** page, select the **Authentication**
card.
3. Click **Set Up SAML Connection**.
4. Enter a domain to add an authorization profile and click **Continue**.
* Ensure that the domain has at least one verified user. The user claiming the
domain must be the same user who created the account and must be logged
into HPE GreenLake platform.
For example, to claim an acme.com domain, the user must be logged in to
HPE GreenLake platform with
an @acme.com email address.
* HPE GreenLake platform does not
support adding other free public domain names such as Gmail.com,
Yahoo.com, or Facebook.com, for SAML authorization profiles.
5. Follow the directions on the **Add SAML Connection** wizard to complete the
SSO setup. See the step descriptions table for help on each step of the wizard.
6. Click **Next** after each step.
7. Click **Finish** to set up your SSO domain.
When your SSO domain is set up, click **Download Metadata File** if you
want to download the metadata, then click **Exit**.
8. Click **Send Email** to send an email to users to notify them that SSO is
enabled for their account, or you can select the **Skip For Now** link to
send an email later.
| Step | Description |
| --- | --- |
| Step 1 of 4 **Add  Identity Provider Details** | |
| Select a Configuration Method | Select one of the following options to add  identity provider details:  * **Metadata File**. The metadata file  must be in XML format and must include a valid  certificate and HTTPS URLs for the entity ID, login  URL, and logout URL fields. 1. Select  **Metadata File**, then click **Upload  Metadata File** to upload the file. HPE GreenLake platform extracts the entity  ID, domain login URL, domain logout URL, and  certificate content. 2. Verify the details, then click  **Save**. * **Metadata URL**. The HTTPS URLs for  the entity ID, login URL, and logout URL fields must  be valid. 1. Select **Metadata  URL** then enter the URL to the page where the  identity provider details are available. 2. Click **Validate URL**.  Details are automatically filled in  for valid configurations. 3. Click  **Save**. * **Manual (Enter X.509 Certificate  Details)** 1. Select **Manual (Enter X.509  Certificate Details)** then enter values in the  **Entity ID**, **Domain Login URL**,  **Domain Logout URL**, and **X.509 Signing  Certificate** fields. 2. Click  **Save**. |
| Step 2 of 4  **Configure Settings** | |
| Map SAML Attributes | Map the SAML attributes you configured on  the IdP to HPE GreenLake platform attributes.  * **Required Attributes** **Email address**. Select  either **NameId** or **Custom** from the  drop-down list depending on how this attribute is  configured on the IdP server. If you use a custom  attribute, make sure it contains the user's email  address. The **NameID** attribute must include  the email address of the user. For example,  `<NameID>admin@test.com</NameID>`.HPE GreenLake  Attribute: This is a mandatory  attribute. The default value is  **hpe\_ccs\_attribute**. You can also substitute  your own custom value. For more information, see  . * **Optional Attributes**  **First Name**, **Last  Name** If you do not configure **First Name** and **Last Name** as  optional attributes, the user's name displays as  `Unknown First Name` and  `Unknown Last Name` in the user's HPE  user account profile. |
| Manage Idle Session Timeout | Specify a value for **Idle Session  Timeout**. |
| Step 3 of 4  **Create a Recovery User** | |
| Recovery User | A recovery user is a fallback user account  you can use to log in and recover the account if there  is an error in the SSO configuration and users are  locked out. If the recovery user details are lost, the  recovery user is specified in the format:  `sso_re_<GLCP account ID  >@yourdomain.com` **Enable Recovery User**. Enable the recovery user option if it is not  already enabled by sliding the **Recovery User**  toggle to the right, then enter values in the following  fields. WARNING: If you disable the recovery user feature,  you can no longer recover your account credentials if an  SSO failure occurs. * **Recovery User Email**. Copy the value in the recovery user email  field. This email is auto generated and you cannot  change it. * **Recovery User Password**. Enter  a password for the recovery user. * **Point of Contact Email**. Enter  a point of contact email in case you forget your  password. This email is used for password recovery  in case the recovery user's password is forgotten  or has expired.  It is recommended that you configure  an email alias to protect against lockout if the  single user with the email is not active in the  company.Copy and store the recovery user details in a  safe place. |
| Step 4 of 4 **Review &  Create** | Check the information displayed and verify  that all your configuration details are correct. Click  **Modify** to edit your configuration details for a  step. |

At any point during or after the service evaluation period, you can request a quote
for a paid service subscription. If you convert to a paid subscription during the
evaluation period, any data you created or configurations you made using the service
during the evaluation period are carried forward to the paid service
subscription.

1. On the **Services** page, click the **Catalog** tab.
2. In the Services Catalog section, search for the name of the relevant service,
either **Compute Ops Management** or **Backup & Recovery**.
3. Click the service card.
4. On the service page, click **Get Quote**.
A product shop page for the service is displayed.
5. In the More Information section, locate the product offering you are interested
in, then click **Request Quote.**
6. On the **Your Carts** page, click **Request Quote.**
7. On the **Get Quote** page, fill in the information requested then click
**Get Quote**.
An HPE sales support
representative will email you shortly to provide details about the pricing
options available.
If you decide to pay for a subscription to the service, configuration data
you created during the evaluation period is available with the paid service.
If you decide not to subscribe to the service, you no longer have access to
the configuration data.
When you delete the client ID and secret, you invalidate all tokens associated with\nthe ID and secret

1. Click the ellipsis next to the Generate Access Token button to
delete your client credentials.
2. Select the Delete Credentials link.
NOTE:
If a user is deleted from HPE GreenLake platform , any tokens or client IDs generated and associated
with any services owned by this user will no longer be valid.

Review and manage the tags in your workspace from the **Tags** tab of the
**Devices** page. The Tags section shows all the tags you have assigned to
resources in your workspace, and all the resources that have been assigned a
specific tag.

1. On the **Devices** page, select the **Tags** tab.
All the tags in your workspace are listed by default. To
refine the list of tags, use the search field to search for a tag by name or
value. You can also sort the tags list using the **Name** or **Value**
columns.
2. To view all the resources that are assigned a specific tag, click the ellipsis
**(…)** next to a tag and select **View Resources**.
All devices that are assigned the tag are listed in the Inventory section of
the **Devices** page.
3. Select one or more devices from the list to manage tags for the devices, then
from the **Actions** drop-down, select **Manage Tags**.
The **Manage Tags on Resources** dialog is displayed. If you
selected one device in the previous step, all tags assigned to the device are
listed. If you selected more than one device, only tags that are assigned to all
the selected devices are shown.
4. Edit the tag assignments as required.
* To add a new or existing tag to the device or devices, select or create a name
and value pair in the **Name** and **Value** fields, then
click **Assign**.
* To delete an existing tag from the device or devices, click the **X** icon
for the tag.
NOTE: Changes you make to tags on the **Manage Tags on
Resources** dialog apply to all the devices you selected.
5. Click **Save Changes**.
The **Tags** column of each device listed in the Inventory section of
the **Devices** page is updated to reflect your changes.
Administrators can easily create and manage new customer workspaces.

1. Log in to your workspace as an administrator.
2. On the Customers page, click the **Add Customer**
button.
The Create Custom Workspace wizard appears.
3. Enter the required information in the fields provided.
1. Company Name, Description, and Company Address.
2. Maximum character entries: Company Name and Description fields have a
125 maximum character limit.
NOTE: Exceeding the maximum allowed characters will result in an error
message, and you will only be able to create the workspace once the
error is corrected.
4. Click Create Workspace to create the workspace.

You must assign a subscription to a device before you can activate\nand use the device

Each device expires individually. If you have multiple devices and the expiration\ndate varies, the devices are unsubscribed from HPE GreenLake platform according to the device expiration dates. Users\nreceive an expiry notification at the subscription expiration date.

1. On the Devices page, click the **Inventory** tab.
2. In the Inventory section, click the Require
Subscriptions card to display all devices requiring
subscriptions.
3. Select the device or devices to which you want to apply a license key.
4. From the Actions drop-down, click Apply
Subscription.
5. On the Apply Subscriptions to Device page, click
Apply Subscriptions to apply subscriptions keys to
the selected devices.
6. On the Apply
Subscriptions to Devices dialog, select a Subscription
Tier and Subscription Key to assign to
the devices listed.
NOTE: See  for a table mapping
the device type to the corresponding subscription tiers for network
devices.
7. Click Apply Subscriptions.
8. Click Finish.
The Subscriptions Applied confirmation dialog appears. The transaction is
recorded in the audit log and you have the option to view the audit logs
from the confirmation dialog.
9. Click Close to exit the confirmation dialog.
The Devices page opens and you can view the updated device details
in the Inventory list.

HPE GreenLake for Backup and Recovery is a data protection service that is part of Data Services Cloud Console on the HPE GreenLake platform. The service enables you to back up and restore: \nVMware virtual machines and datastores
AWS EBS volumes, EC2 instances, RDS instances
Cloud native Kubernetes applications that are running in your EKS clusters
Microsoft SQL Server databases and instances
HPE array volumes
The service features a comprehensive dashboard that displays the overall status of your protected resources as well as detailed protection reports.

Users of this service must have a valid subscription and an account in HPE GreenLake Cloud Portal with the appropriate roles. For information on creating a new HPE GreenLake account and setting up and assigning roles, see the HPE GreenLake for Backup and Recovery Getting Started Guide.
To get started using Backup and Recovery, complete the following steps:

VMware protection initial setup. To protect your on-premises resources, you must first deploy the Data Orchestrator and Protection Store Gateway These two on-premises components run in virtual machines in a user-specified vCenter. The Data Orchestrator is used by the Data Services Cloud Console to provide local orchestration of backup and recovery operations. The Protection Store Gateway provides on-premises storage and access to cloud storage for the backups.
NOTE: StoreOnce users can elect to deploy a Protection Store Gateway or to register a StoreOnce appliance as a backup target.
For information about the supported configurations for the VMware infrastructure, the Data Orchestrator, and the Protection Store Gateway, refer to Backup and Recovery QuickSpecs.

To protect VMware resources, you must also register a vCenter Server. Registering a vCenter Server enables Backup and Recovery to identify the virtual machines and datastores on your vCenter Server and build an inventory of the assets that can be protected. Note that you must have the required vCenter privileges to register a vCenter server.
To protect AWS resources, you must register an AWS account. Registering an AWS account enables Backup and Recovery to identify and build an inventory of all your AWS assets that can be protected.
To protect Microsoft SQL Server resources that are hosted in VMware virtual machines, you must:
Register a vCenter Server
Register an application host

Registering an application host enables Backup and Recovery to identify the Microsoft SQL databases and instances in your Microsoft account and to build an inventory of the assets that can be protected.
Create a protection policy.

A protection policy is a collection of protection rules that defines the creation and life-cycle management of the protection copies (recovery points). You can protect any unprotected resources in the inventory by assigning a protection policy to a resource.
Create an application-specific protection group.

Protection groups are used to automate protection at scale. Resources that require the same level of protection can be allocated to application-specific protection groups. Associating a protection policy with a protection group rather than individual resources simplifies the process of protecting multiple resources.
Recover your backups.
To recover a backed up resource from your recovery points, use the recover feature. This feature enables you to choose which recovery point to use and where to direct the recovered resource.
About this task
The following procedure outlines the steps to set up HPE GreenLake for Backup and Recovery for protection of on-premises and cloud assets. Other pages describe these steps in more detail.
Procedure
Log into an HPE account.
If you do not have an account, you must create one.
Select a workspace.
If there is no workspace or you want to run Backup and Recovery in a new workspace,you must create one.
Create or invite users.
Assign Backup and Recovery user roles.
Add the Backup and Recovery subscription key to your HPE GreenLake workspace by clicking the Manage Your Subscription link in your subscription contract receipt email.
For more detail see the Adding subscription to services from the subscription notification email message page in the HPE GreenLake Edge-to-Cloud Platform User Guide.
Click the Identity and Access tile to verify that the built-in roles are sufficient or create custom roles to enable access to HPE GreenLake for Backup and Recovery.
Launch the Data Services Cloud Console in the required region.
Select Launch from HPE GreenLake for Backup and Recovery tile.
Two options are available from the HPE GreenLake for Backup and Recovery dashboard.
Continue by selecting one of the following two procedures to complete the set-up process.
Completing the HPE GreenLake for Backup and Recovery set-up process to protect cloud data
Completing the HPE GreenLake for Backup and Recovery set-up process to protect on-premises data
Complete the steps in Preview of setting up HPE GreenLake for Backup and Recovery before starting this process.
Procedure
Complete the steps in the AWS setup wizard.
Download the CloudFormation Stack template.
Apply the template in your AWS account to create an AWS CloudFormation Stack with your credentials.
Validate the link between AWS and HPE Backup and Recovery service console.
At this point all EC2 instances, EBS volumes, and RDS instances show up within the HPE Backup and Recovery inventory.
Results
You are now ready to backup your AWS cloud native assets.
Complete the steps in Preview of setting up HPE GreenLake for Backup and Recovery before starting this process.
About this task
If you want to use an HPE StoreOnce system to store on-premises recovery points, you can skip the first step and refer to HPE StoreOnce appliances.
Procedure
Install and configure Data Orchestrator to provide a secure connection from the on-premises environment to the cloud hosted service.
Install and configure the Protection Store Gateway to manage the On-Premises Protection Store and Cloud Protection Store.

The installation of the two virtual machines to your vCenter environment is a one-time operation. After the deployment, the Backup and Recovery Service manages and automatically updates the Data Orchestrator and Protection Store Gateway.

HPE StoreOnce appliances can be connected to HPE GreenLake for Backup and Recovery to provide on-premises backup storage as an alternative to a Protection Store Gateway-hosted On-Premises Protection Store. When the On-Premises Protection Store is configured on a StoreOnce appliance and the backup location is physically separate from the protected environment, you need to install the Data Orchestrator. You must have compute resources, memory resources or both in order to run the Data Orchestrator VM.
When using a StoreOnce appliance for the On-Premises Protection Store, note the following:
Only physical StoreOnce appliances are supported, the StoreOnce VSA is not supported.
The StoreOnce appliance must be running Storeonce software 4.3.4 or later.
An encryption license must be installed on StoreOnce.
iSCSI and Fibre Channel is supported for the backup data path.
Network time protocol servers (NTP) must be configured and be allowed to sync with global time services.

Locate the HPE Cloud invitation email you should have received from HPE. This email contains a link that will take you directly to the HPE Sign In page. If you have a current HPE user account (HPE Support or HPE InfoSight), use the same credentials to sign in, and then go to Creating an HPE GreenLake workspace. If you do not have a current user account, do the following to create one.
Procedure
In the HPE Cloud invitation email, click HPE Set Up Account. Or, go to https://common.cloud.hpe.com and click Sign up at the bottom of the page.
In the Create an HPE Account page, specify your account information, and then click Create Account.
Monitor your email account for a verification email. Click Verify Email to verify your identity.
By creating the HPE GreenLake workspace, you are by default the super admin for the account.
Prerequisites
To complete this procedure, you must have an existing HPE user account.
Procedure
If you are not already, log in to your HPE GreenLake user account.
Click Create Workspace.
Provide the following information:
Workspace Name
Workspace Country
Street Address
City, State
ZIP/Postal Code
Phone Number
Email
Accept the legal terms.
Click Create Workspace.
Your workspace dashboard opens.
For a zero-cost evaluation of the service, you can get a 90-day evaluation subscription.
You have access to the same features and experience with an evaluation subscription as with a purchased subscription, with the following caveats:
The subscription runs for 90 days. A one-time 90-day extension is available at the discretion of HPE.
The Cloud Protection Store consumption is limited to 5TB.
There is no billing for usage.
You can request the subscription using a webform on the HPE GreenLake for Backup and Recovery page. Complete the webform using an organizational email address, not a web email (e.g., Gmail) address.
After HPE receives the evaluation request for the HPE GreenLake for Backup and Recovery evaluation subscription, you will receive an acknowledgment email.
If the request is approved, you will receive another email that contains details on how to acquire the subscription key and start the evaluation.
In most cases, if the request is accepted, you will receive the second email a few minutes after the request is submitted. If it is not received in 24 hours, contact HPE Support.

At any time during the evaluation, you can add a Pay As You Go (PAYG) subscription or for lower unit prices add a subscription with a defined duration and defined level of service consumption. This will enable your ongoing use of HPE GreenLake for Backup and Recovery with no interruption to operation.

If you do not add a paid subscription to the HPE GreenLake Cloud Portal workspace, within 90-days of the start of the evaluation subscription, access to HPE GreenLake for Backup and Recovery will be blocked after 90-days.
You need to work with your HPE partner or HPE representative to get a quote for the subscription.
After HPE receives a purchase order, the existing subscription is updated to the purchased subscription and access to the service continues uninterrupted.
NOTE: If you do not upgrade before the end of the evaluation, you need to add a new key to the HPE GreenLake workspace.
To manage the storage array, you need to add it to Data Services Cloud Console.
Prerequisites

You should have received an email with the array serial number and subscription key. You will need both to add the array to Data Services Cloud Console. If you do not have this information, skip this procedure until you obtain it. Consider the following resources:
The array serial number is also located on the rear of the array, on either a pull-out tab, or a label.
Later in the setup process, when you are connecting the array to HPE GreenLake (Software Configuration > Connect Array), the Cloud Connectivity Wizard will display the subscription key.
Procedure
On your workspace Home page, click Devices.
On the Devices Inventory page, click Add Devices.
On the Select Device Type page, select Storage Devices as the Device Type, and then click Next.
On the Enter Serial Number & Subscription Key page:
Select Purchase or Lease as the Ownership Type.
Type the device Serial Number and Subscription Key.
Click Enter.
Repeat these steps for each additional device.
When done, click Next.
On the Assign Tags page, optionally assign tags to the device. Tags are used to organize/label inventory resources. Click Next.
On the Location and Service Delivery Contact page, optionally assign a Location and Service Delivery Contact and Location, and then click Next.
On the Review Add Devices page, verify your information, and then click Finish.
Back on the Device Inventory page, if the device is not already assigned to a Data Services Cloud Console instance, select the device, and then select Assign to Service Manager from the Actions menu.

On the Assign Devices to Service Manager Instance page, select Data Services Cloud Console for the Service Manager, and then select the Region closest to where you are installing the the device. Click Finish, and then Close.
Back on the Devices Inventory page, verify that the array is listed and that it is assigned to the correct Data Services Cloud Console instance.
This procedure describes how to validate your device's connection to the Data Services Cloud Console.
Prerequisites
Ensure you have:
Received access to the activation portal and instructions to add your storage system.
Received instructions on cloud connectivity requirements for the new storage system including endpoints that must be reached through the internet (might require proxy configuration).
Racked and cabled your system.
Use one of the following tools to validate the device's connection to the Data Services Cloud Console:
CURL
Netcat
PowerShell
Procedure
Identify the gateway required to reach the internet from your storage system.
Identify the proxy server (if any) required to reach the internet from your storage system.
Establish a connection to https://common.cloud.hpe.com.
Ensure the device (arrays) can connect to device.cloud.hpe.com and*.data.cloud.hpe.com (if your organization allows wildcards).
Confirm the proxy server will not change or interfere with certificates between your storage system and servers of common.cloud.hpe.com.
Ensure the DNS servers are configured correctly and will resolve servers on cloud.hpe.com and subdomains.
Sync your NTP server's time with time.google.com or one of the nist.gov time servers.
The storage system connects to TCP port 443 using HTTPS on servers on subdomains of common.cloud.hpe.com.
Add the Allow Connection Policy to TCP port 443 for *.data.cloud.hpe.com in the firewall.
NOTE: These URLs are dynamically provided based on the region. They are not reachable until the devices are activated and onboarded.
If device.cloud.hpe.com and *.data.cloud.hpe.com can be reached and the subscription is validated, the Customer Self Install (CSI) process continues.

If device.cloud.hpe.com and *.data.cloud.hpe.com cannot be reached, or the subscription is not valid, the CSI process stops. A message displays providing guidance for why the validation was unsuccessful. You will have the option to return to the network settings page (to fix networking issues) or retry the subscription validation check. Once the issue is resolved, you will be allowed to continue through the CSI process.
To use the Data Services Cloud Console, you must add it to your HPE GreenLake workspace.
Procedure
On your workspace Home page, click Find Services in the Getting Started section.
On the Services page, scroll to the Storage section, and then click Data Services.
On the Data Services page, click Provision.
In the Provision Service Manager dialog box, select the Deployment Region physically closest to the array, accept the Terms of Service, and then click Deploy.
Optional:If you are deploying multiple arrays in different regions, click Add Region, and then deploy the additional regions.
At the top of the page, click Launch to open Data Services Cloud Console.
You must be an account administrator or a user with edit permissions through the Authorization service to assign roles to users.
About this task
Keep the following notes in mind:
Users cannot update or add role assignments for federated users within HPE GreenLake workspaces.
This procedure applies to users in a standalone tenant workspace. All tenant user role assignments take place and are managed within the tenant workspace.
Procedure
From the HPE GreenLake top menu bar, go to Manage > Identity & Access .
On the Identity & Access page, click Assign a Role on the Assign Roles card.
In the Assign Role dialog box, select a user from the User drop-down list.
From the Application drop-down list, select the application for which you need to grant permissions.
In the Role field, select a role for the user. You can enter text to search for a role or pick one from the list.
The options vary depending on the application that you select.
Click Assign Role to add the assignment.
In the Change Role Assignment? confirmation box, review the requested role assignment details and click Change Role Assignment.
The updated role assignment is saved. Role assignment changes can take up to 15 minutes to take effect.
To verify the update, perform the following steps:
Select Users on the Identity & Access Management page.
Click the user's name to view their newly added role in the Details screen.

The Aruba SD-Branch solution offers the best-in-class wireless and wired infrastructure, as well as management orchestration features with the SD-WAN capabilities. The SD-Branch solution extends the SD-WAN concept to all elements in the branch to deliver a full-stack solution that addresses wired and wireless Local Area Network (LAN), security and policy enforcement, and WAN connectivity. When combined with Aruba Central, the solution provides a cloud-hosted environment for simplified operations and improved agility.

Organizations frequently deploy and manage distributed, diverse networks through small, centralized teams. Apart from WAN connection, these distributed networks provide a variety of other services. Branch networks require wired and wireless LAN, security and policy enforcement, and WAN interconnection.
The SD-Branch solution addresses the following issues:
WAN Connectivity—WAN connectivity allows SD-WAN technology to support the usage of the Internet to replace or augment MPLS services. The SD-WAN solution includes the following elements:
Path Quality Monitoring (PQM) to track the quality of the available paths.
Stateful firewall with application fingerprinting to identify traffic flow.
Dynamic path selection (DPS) to always select the optimal path.
Centralized routing to offload the branch gateways from participating in routing.
User identity information to select from the available paths.

Branch Onboarding and Lifecycle Management—Centralized teams use third-party companies for installations. To bring remote sites online, the corporate team may need to collaborate with these third-party installers from different organizations depending on the geographic locations. This model presents significant logistical and technical challenges. SD-Branch architecture is developed to enable Zero-Touch Provisioning (ZTP) for all branch devices. This feature allows hundreds of locations to be brought up each week. ZTP, when combined with a scalable cloud-based management platform, enables organizations to set up, modify, and maintain networks in an agile manner.

LAN Security and Automation—Modern branch deployments can be excessively complex due to the growth of Virtual Local Area Networks (VLANs), complex Internet Protocol (IP) addressing schemes, and access control lists (ACLs) distributed across multiple devices in the branch. Architectures are customized to the needs of automation software rather than the automation software adapting to the architecture. The SD-Branch architecture flattens the branch into fewer subnets by consolidating all policy enforcement into a single device. This eliminates the need for static IP addressing schemes and hardwired ACLs across multiple devices.

An access point (AP) is a wireless network device that acts as a portal for devices to connect to a local area network. The built-in network intelligence in access points supports advanced capabilities like AI-powered RF optimization, dynamic segmentation, service assurance, and smart management options for improved IT and user experiences. APs are used to extend an existing network's wireless coverage and increase the number of users that can connect to it.
Aruba Central supports the following types of access points based on the operating system:
IAP—Instant Access Points (IAPs) run on ArubaInstant operating system that virtualizes Aruba Mobility Controller capabilities on 802.11 APs and offers a feature-rich enterprise-grade Wi-Fi solution.

ArubaOS 10 AP—ArubaOS 10 APs run on ArubaOS 10 operating system that requires no manual CLI configuration or maintenance windows. Once the ArubaOS 10 AP is plugged in, the device connects and receives its running configuration from the cloud using zero-touch provisioning, allowing remote workers and sites to onboard and configure wireless connectivity without on-site IT support.
Instant APs

Instant Access Points (IAPs) offer an enterprise-grade networking solution with a simple setup. The WLAN solution with IAPs supports simplified deployment, configuration, and management of Wi-Fi networks.

Access Points run the ArubaInstant software that virtualizes ArubaMobility Controller capabilities on 802.11 APs and offers a feature-rich enterprise-grade Wi-Fi solution. IAPs are often deployed as a cluster. An IAP cluster includes a conductor AP and set of other APs that act as member APs.

In an IAP deployment scenario, only the first AP or the conductor AP that is connected to a provisioning network is configured. All other IAPs in the same VLAN join the conductor AP inherit the configuration changes. The IAP clusters are configured through a common interface called Virtual Controller. A Virtual Controller represents the combined intelligence of the IAPs in a cluster.
IAPs establish WebSocket connections with Aruba Central by exchanging TPM certificates.
Supported Deployment Modes
Aruba IAPs can be deployed in the following modes in Aruba Central:

Cluster mode—In this mode, several IAPs form a cluster when connected to a provisioning network and a conductor Instant AP is elected. In the cluster mode, new IAP onboarded to Aruba Central can join an existing Instant AP cluster.
Standalone mode—In this mode, individual IAPs are provisioned in groups and managed from Aruba Central.
Configuration and Management
Network administrators can manage IAPs through the Aruba Instant UI, Aruba Central, or AirWave management system.
For information on how to configure IAPs using the Aruba Instant UI, see the Aruba Instant User Guide.
For more information on how to provision, configure, and monitor IAPs in Aruba Central, see the following topics:
Configuring Instant APs in Aruba Central
Monitoring Access Points in Aruba Central
ArubaOS 10 APs

ArubaOS 10 access points run on a cloud-managed operating system that requires no manual CLI configuration or maintenance windows. This makes them easy to deploy and manage, even for large networks. Once the ArubaOS 10 AP is plugged in, the device connects to the cloud and receives its running configuration automatically using zero-touch provisioning. This allows remote workers and sites to onboard and configure wireless connectivity without on-site IT support.

The ArubaOS 10 APs support a number of new features and capabilities, including cloud-based AI, 802.11k/v/r Wi-Fi security standards, WPA3 encryption method, and Dynamic Authorization. These APs also offer advanced scalability to meet the needs of any network size.
Supported Deployment Modes
ArubaOS 10 APs can be deployed in the following modes in Aruba Central:

Bridge mode—In this mode, the ArubaOS 10 APs act as simple wireless bridges between the wireless interface and the wired network deployed at a site. This mode is typically used for small networks or for connecting remote APs to a wired network. For information on configuring ArubaOS 10 APs in a LAN setup in bridge mode, see Bridge Mode Deployment.

Tunnel mode—In this mode, the ArubaOS 10 APs tunnel all traffic to a central controller. The ArubaOS 10 APs set up a secure mobility tunnel for clients that roam between the VLANs, and the client traffic is encapsulated and routed to a tunnel endpoint. This mode is typically used for larger networks or for networks that require centralized management. For information on configuring ArubaOS 10 APs in a LAN setup in tunnel mode, see Tunnel and Mixed Mode Deployment.

Mixed mode—In this mode, the ArubaOS 10 APs are configured in bridge mode and tunnel mode. In mixed mode, the ArubaOS 10 APs can intelligently determine if client traffic must be bridged or tunneled based on the client VLAN. This mode is typically used for networks that have a mix of small and large deployments. For information on configuring ArubaOS 10 APs in a LAN setup in mixed mode, see Tunnel and Mixed Mode Deployment.

Aruba switches enable secure, role-based network access for wired users and devices, independent of their location or application. With Aruba switches, enterprises can deploy a consistent and secure access to network resources based on the type of users, client devices, and connection methods.

Aruba offers a wide range of switches from edge access to data center, all managed by a modern operating system, which is cloud-native and fully programmable. It provides a simplified network design and unified management across the entire network.
Aruba Central offers the following switches:
AOS-S - For detailed information, see AOS-S Switches Overview
AOS-CX - For detailed information, see AOS-CX Overview
Refer to the following sections for more information:
Monitoring Switches in Summary View
Monitoring Switches in List View
Configuring or Viewing AOS-S Properties in UI Groups
Configuring AOS-CX Switches in UI Groups
Configuring and Viewing AOS-CX Switches in MultiEdit Mode

AOS-CX is a modern and fully programmable operating system built using a database-centric design, which ensures higher availability and dynamic software process changes for reduced downtime. In addition to robust hardware reliability, the AOS-CX operating system includes additional software elements not available with traditional systems, including:
Automated visibility to help IT organizations scale
Simplified programmability
Faster resolution with network insights
High availability
Ease of roll-back to previous configurations

The AOS-CX operating system is a modular, database-centric operating system. Every aspect of the switch configuration and state information is modeled in the AOS-CX switch configuration and state database, including configuration information, status of all features, and network analytics. The AOS-CX operating system also includes a time series database, which acts as a built-in network record. The time series database makes the data seamlessly available to Aruba Network Analytics Engine agents that use rules that evaluate network conditions over time.

Aruba Central offers a cloud-based management platform for managing AOS-CX infrastructure. It simplifies switch management with flexible configuration options, monitoring dashboards, and troubleshooting tools.

Starting from Aruba Central 2.5.8, users can onboard, monitor their devices, and upgrade the AOS-CX firmware over IPv6 or dual stack networks. It is recommended for the switches to run AOS-CX 10.13.1000 or later versions to onboard their devices over IPv6 networks. Before you onboard devices over IPv6 or dual stack networks, ensure that the following prerequisites are met.
IPv6 address must be configured for one touch provisioning. Aruba Central does not support IPv6 ZTP support.
Device location override should be enabled.

Aruba switches enable secure, role-based network access for wired users and devices, independent of their location or application. With Aruba switches, enterprises can deploy a consistent and secure access to network resources based on the type of users, client devices, and connection methods.

Aruba Central offers a cloud-based management platform for managing Aruba switch infrastructure. It simplifies switch management with flexible configuration options, monitoring dashboards, and troubleshooting tools.
The switch dashboard enables you to manage, configure, monitor and troubleshoot AOS-S, AOS-CX switches, and switch stacks provisioned and managed through Aruba Central.

Gateways in Aruba Central provide high-performance networking, SD-WAN, and security functionality. You can monitor gateways using all available filters, including Global, Groups, and Sites. Multiple gateways can be combined into groups and multiple groups can be combined into clusters. You can designate the role of Preferred Leader to individual gateways in each group.

The Aruba SD-Branch solution deploys a hardware VPNC as the headend gateway in the customer's data center or a virtual gateway in your public cloud infrastructure. The virtualized instance of Aruba Gateway is referred to as Virtual Gateway.
Virtual Gateways bring your public cloud infrastructure on the SD-WAN fabric to facilitate the connectivity between the branches and the public cloud.
Virtual Gateways in the Aruba SD-WAN architecture offer the following benefits:
Direct connection from branch to cloud instances which improves the access to the instances hosted on a public cloud infrastructure.
Resilient connectivity from the cloud using multiple transport links; for example, the link between an Internet Gateway and Virtual Gateway.
Centralized control and policy management across branch, data center, and cloud end-points.

With Virtual Gateways, you can extend your SD-WAN overlay services to the public cloud infrastructure. Virtual Gateways function as VPNCs in the SD-WAN architecture. Virtual Gateways can terminate tunnels from Branch Gateways, Instant APs (micro SD-Branches with Instant APs) and VIA clients. Like the on-premises VPNCs, Virtual Gateways support routing, security, and tunneling features.
Virtual Gateway Redundancy
Aruba supports deploying Virtual Gateways for high availability (HA). The Virtual Gateways can be deployed in the HA mode and also can be deployed in multiple availability zones.
Software Image for Virtual Gateways
The software images required for creating Virtual Gateway instances are available as an AMI. To obtain the AMI for a Virtual Gateway, contact your Aruba Sales Specialist.
Aruba Central offers the following options to configure gateways in Aruba Central:

Groups—You can create a logical subset of devices as groups. If you have devices that must share common configuration settings, ensure that you assign these devices to the same group. Any new device joining a group inherits the configuration that is already applied to the devices in a group. Similarly, you can also maintain separate groups for Branch Gateways and VPNCs by assigning a group role for the devices. For more information, see Assign Gateways to a Group.

Device-specific configuration—If you have a considerably lesser number of devices that do not have the same configuration requirements, you can apply configuration changes at the device level. In some cases, although the devices are assigned to a group, you may want to have a slightly different configuration to one specific device in a group. In such cases, you can modify the device configuration and apply changes at the device level. Aruba Central marks the discrepancies in the group and device configuration as overrides on the Configuring Configuration Audit Properties page.
Bulk configuration—Aruba Central supports several bulk configuration options for Aruba Gateways:

Bulk Configuration Upload—Allows you to download a list of Aruba Gateways from Aruba Central in the CSV file format. You can add the configuration parameters for hostname, system IP address, VLAN, and Ports, and then upload the CSV file to Aruba Central. For more information, see Uploading Bulk Configuration Template.

Gateway Pools—Allows you to create a common pool of IP addresses and enables automatic assignment of IP addresses to Aruba Gateways. For more information, see Configuring Gateway Pools for Aruba Gateways.

DHCP Pools—Allows you to configure a DHCP pool, using which Aruba Central automatically assigns a subnet to each Aruba Gateway for a given VLAN. For more information, see Configuring Gateway Pools for Aruba Gateways.
APIs—Allows you to configure and monitor devices using NB APIs. For more information, see API Gateway.
Aruba Central supports the following methods to configure ArubaOS 10 Gateway groups and Gateways.

Guided Setup—You can use the Guided Setup to quickly configure basic and essential parameters on ArubaOS 10 Gateways for deploying the SD-WAN solution. The Guided Setup provides a wizard-based workflow for provisioning ArubaOS 10 Gateways. The wizard allows you to configure ArubaOS 10 Gateways at your own pace, pause, and resume when required. However, the Guided Setup will not be available after you complete the provisioning workflow for an ArubaOS 10 Gateway group or an ArubaOS 10 Gateway.
For more information on configuring ArubaOS 10 Gateways using the Guided Setup, see the following topics:
Guided Setup for ArubaOS 10 Branch Gateways
Guided Setup for ArubaOS 10 VPNCs
Guided Setup for ArubaOS 10 VPNC Groups
Guided Setup for ArubaOS 10 Mobility Gateways
Configuring ArubaOS 10 Mobility Gateway Groups Using the Guided Setup

Basic Mode—Allows you to configure your ArubaOS 10 Gateways in a non-linear fashion. This mode allows you to make configuration changes after you provision your ArubaOS 10 gateways for the first time using a Guided setup. For more information, see Configuring an SD-Branch Network Using the Basic Setup for ArubaOS 10 Personas.
Advanced Mode—Allows you to configure advanced features for SD-WAN deployments. For more information, see Configuring an SD-Branch Network Using the Advanced Setup for ArubaOS 10 Personas.

Cloud Authentication and Policy allows you to configure user and client access policies that provide a secured, cloud-based network access control (NAC). In Aruba Central, you can configure these policies and provide an on-boarding URL for the network users to connect to the network. As the users attempt to connect to the network, you can monitor the authentication access requests and sessions on the monitoring dashboards. You can view more details of each access request and session to analyze them or identify any issues.
Ensure that you have completed the following procedures:
Gateways are onboarded to Aruba Central.
Gateways are assigned valid subscriptions in Aruba Central.
Gateways are assigned to groups.
Gateways are assigned the Branch Gateway group role.

To deliver the value of ML and data science to your enterprise, the HPE GreenLake platform delivers an enterprise-grade ML cloud service that enables developers and data scientists to rapidly build, train, and deploy ML models—from pilot to production, at any scale. This preconfigured solution comprises an optimized hardware stack and is powered by HPE Ezmeral ML Ops. It provides data scientists with self-service access to a sandbox environment for prototyping and testing, to eliminate IT provisioning delays, ensure repeatability, and accelerate time-to-value. And as a fully managed solution, the HPE GreenLake offering frees IT from routine infrastructure management tasks.
You must launch HPE GreenLake Flex Solutions to access ML Ops. If you do not have access to ML Ops, it will not be visible in HPE GreenLake Flex Solutions.

Formerly known as HPE GreenLake Central, view usage and cost of HPE GreenLake Flex Solutions and manage the Private Cloud Enterprise and High Performance Computing cloud services. For all HPE GreenLake Flex Solutions, this service provides reporting on billing, active capacity planning, and powerful consumption analytics that enable transparency to see costs by service type, department, or other parameters, including public cloud costs. Customers of Private Cloud Enterprise use it to provision and manage virtual, containerized, and bare metal resources, and customers of High Performance Computing use it to operate HPC workloads.
